content: The Act is titled the "Flexibility for Individual Excellence in Education Act of 2007" and includes modifications to amendments made by the No Child Left Behind Act of 2001. The "Flexibility for Individual Excellence in Education Act of 2007" includes modifications to the Highly Qualified Teacher Standard, allowing middle or secondary teachers new to the profession to use a college minor. It also extends the deadline for rural schools to meet all standards until the 2011-12 school year, with an additional $50 million authorized to help them meet the standards. The Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965 is amended to ensure that all teachers in rural school districts are highly qualified by the end of the 2011-2012 school year. The Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965 is amended to provide additional funding for grants under subpart 2 for teacher recruitment, retention, and meeting eligibility criteria for teachers in rural school districts. In subpart 2, $50,000,000 is authorized for teacher recruitment, retention, and professional development in rural school districts for fiscal year 2008 and subsequent years. Additionally, Title I of the Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965 is amended to limit highly qualified teacher rules to teachers of core subjects. SEC. 1005 limits the definition of highly qualified teachers to teachers of core subjects in the Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965. The amendment allows for the assessment of students with disabilities at their instructional level in core subjects, as defined in the Individuals with Disabilities Education Act. The amendment allows for assessing students with disabilities below their enrolled grade level in core academic subjects using State assessments aligned with their instructional level. The Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965 is amended to include measures of students' progress towards proficiency, multiple measures of student academic achievement, and assessing students with disabilities below their enrolled grade level in core academic subjects using State assessments aligned with their instructional level. The Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965 is amended to include measures of student progress towards proficiency based on individual student achievement gains over time, disaggregated by student groups. Adequate Yearly Progress is determined by group and subject, identifying schools in need of improvement if the same group of students fails in the same academic subject. The Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965 is amended to include measures of student progress towards proficiency based on individual student achievement gains over time, disaggregated by student groups. Adequate Yearly Progress is determined by group and subject, identifying schools in need of improvement if the same group of students fails in the same academic subject. Specifically, the amendment focuses on ensuring that almost every student in each group enrolled in a school is meeting or exceeding the State's proficient level of academic achievement in a subject where there is a failure. The text discusses the requirements for identifying schools failing to make adequate yearly progress in academic subjects, as outlined in the State's plan. If a group of students fails to meet the requirements for identification and make progress after two years, the local educational agency must take action. The text discusses the identification of schools failing to make progress in academic subjects. If a group of students continues to fail after corrective action, the local educational agency must intervene. The identification process must be specific to groups and subjects. The text discusses the identification of failing schools and the need for specific interventions for groups of students in academic subjects. The text discusses interventions for failing schools, including offering supplemental educational services or public school choice for schools identified for improvement. Amendments are made to sections 1111(b)(2)(C)(v), 1116(b)(5)(A), 1116(b)(7)(C)(i), and 1116(b)(8)(A)(i) of the Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965. The local educational agency must provide students in identified groups with the option to transfer to another public school not identified for improvement or offer supplemental educational services. The local educational agency must offer supplemental educational services to students in identified groups in the academic subject related to their identification. If multiple schools or groups are identified, the agency must make the same choice for all. The local educational agency must offer transfer options or supplemental educational services to identified groups of students who fail to make adequate yearly progress in an academic subject after the first full school year of identification. The local educational agency must offer transfer options or supplemental educational services to students who fail to make adequate yearly progress in an academic subject. The agency must choose one of the services available under clause (ii) and continue to provide technical assistance.
